abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings convey unsatisfactory
            project outcomes, unlikely sustainability, and modest
            institutional development impacts. Lessons highlight the
            importance of implementing legislative actions prior to loan
            effectiveness, and, the Bank should ensure that sector
            policy, and reform objectives are recorded in a formal
            Letter of Development Policy, regardless whether or not,
            there is an apparent commitment to sector reforms by the
            government. Furthermore, the Bank should not underestimate
            the magnitude of resistance by trade unions and the
            difficulties this brings along to staff, corporate
            management, and the government itself, nor the time required
            to develop sufficient consensus, needed to address
            structural changes in large organizations requiring major
            staff reduction. Similarly, the Bank should not rely on
            studies and expected implementation of their recommendations
            as part of conditionality, an approach by nature too vague,
            difficult to manage, and almost impossible to enforce.
            Additionally, in order to ensure commitment and full
            implementation of technical assistance components, clearly
            defined terms of reference, agreed during appraisal, should
            be ensured by the Bank prior to negotiations. As for the
            lending instrument, investment loans are poorly suited to
            support long-term sectoral reforms; had an adjustable
            program loan been available at project design, effective
            gradual support to sector policy changes would have
            minimized risks and costs, securing incremental
            commercialization, and progressive closure of loss making activities.

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the Coal Sector
            Rehabilitation Project are to support India's current
            market-oriented reforms in the coal sector and,
            specifically, to provide financial and technical support to
            India's efforts to make itself commercially viable and
            self sustaining. Underpinning India's broad drive to
            achieve economic growth, the project also aims to increase
            domestic supplies of coal. The project will consist of (a)
            an investment component - high return and quick disbursing
            investments to maintain or improve the profitability of the
            24 existing mine sub-projects; and (b) an assistance and
            training component - a study of the rules and regulations
            governing the coal industry, in light of the
            Government's decision to open up the coal sector to
            private investors; and technical assistance to support
            India's institutional capacity development in project
            implementation and mining operations and management.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Coal Sector Rehabilitation Project
            : environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
Coal is India's most important
            source of commercial energy, currently meeting about
            two-thirds of that country's energy needs. Over the
            past two years, the government of India and Coal India have
            implemented reforms aimed at making the coal industry
            commercially viable and financially self-sustaining. The
            primary objective of the Coal Sector Rehabilitation Project
            is to support this reform agenda and Coal India's
            transformation into a commercial company whose operations
            are environmentally and socially sustainable. In order for
            the program to meet its long-term financial impact, it will
            support investments in opencast and underground mining
            operations that are projected to yield the highest economic
            returns; provide technical assistance in support of the
            program; and assist Coal India in mitigating the adverse
            effects of mining operations on the environment and the
            people directly affected by mining activities.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Coal Sector Rehabilitation Project
            : environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
Coal is India's most important
            source of commercial energy, currently meeting about
            two-thirds of that country's energy needs. Over the
            past two years, the government of India and Coal India have
            implemented reforms aimed at making the coal industry
            commercially viable and financially self-sustaining. The
            primary objective of the Coal Sector Rehabilitation Project
            is to support this reform agenda and Coal India's
            transformation into a commercial company whose operations
            are environmentally and socially sustainable. In order for
            the program to meet its long-term financial impact, it will
            support investments in opencast and underground mining
            operations that are projected to yield the highest economic
            returns; provide technical assistance in support of the
            program; and assist Coal India in mitigating the adverse
            effects of mining operations on the environment and the
            people directly affected by mining activities.
